text:
ROBYN WOODMAN: I would like
to take this opportunity to introduce myself. My name is Robyn Woodman. And I am the Assistant Director
of Professional Programs

here at Stanford Online and
Stanford Engineering Center for Global and Online Education.

Thank you for being here today. And now, I'd like to turn it
over to my colleague, Pax, to introduce himself.
And we can get started. Take it away, Pax. PAX HEHMEYER: Thanks, Robyn. My name is Pax Hehmeyer.

I'm the Director of
Academic Programs here at the Stanford
Engineering Center for Global

and Online Education,
another mouthful. And if you've joined
us before, you might notice the name change.

I'm always mentioning
that, before we were the Stanford Center for
Professional Development. Now we're the Center for
Global and Online Education.

You can call us by our acronym,
which is pronounced CGOE now. So what I want to do right
now, before we go into depth is

to give you a 30,000-foot view
of what we're going to talk about, and also what's
available to you.

What kinds of
learning experiences are available to all of
you at Stanford Online?

So broadly speaking,
there are three buckets. There's a lot of free
content that's available.

This includes entire
lecture courses where you can watch
the recordings. There are program
previews especially

for the professional
programs, webinars, et cetera. There's the
professional programs

which Robyn's going to
go into more detail on. And then there's
the academic credit,

so those are the
actual classes that are happening on
Stanford's campus that you then can take
as an online student

and follow along with
on campus students, you do all the same
assignments and you

earn the same transcript. So which of these
is right for you is going to depend
on your thoughts

about cost, how much time
you have, what kind of space you're going to
want to do it in.

You going to try and do all
this learning in one week, because you have a week free? Well, that's probably
not going to work on the academic side of things.

It might be great
for professional. And it could work very well
in terms of the free content. So there are a lot of
options available to you.

And I encourage you to go to
our website, Stanford online or online.stanford.edu,
take a look at it.

If you're interested in seeing
what's on our YouTube channel, you can just go to the Stanford
Online YouTube channel.

And what you'll see there
are a lot of materials like this webinar
info session today, other webinars that
Robyn or I have

led with faculty about topics. And you'll also find
a lot of material that's produced out of
the Stanford classroom.

And that'll give
you a sense of what our professional and
academic programs are like. It'll also give you a chance
to learn at your own pace,

if you're not interested in
a professional or academic programs. But with that, I'm
going to hand it over to Robyn, who's
going to go into more

detail about the kinds
of professional programs that are available in the
leadership and business transformation area
at Stanford Online.

ROBYN WOODMAN: Thanks, Pax. And thanks for all that context. I think it's so
important to note, we do have so many great
free materials that

are on our website, on our
social channels, on our YouTube. And it might be that those
work out best for you,

and that's awesome. As Pax said, we have a lot of
these webinars and sessions with faculty and great content.

But what we're going
to talk about right now are the professional
education programs that are available within
this content bucket.

So that was the middle box
that Pax had on the last slide.

So there are three programs
in the leadership and business portfolio. And as you can see
at the top here,

they are fully online
and self-paced. This means it's
Tuesday at 3:00 PM,

your courses. They are ready and available to
you at all times, self-paced. We have lots of learners that to
do these over their lunch hour.

Maybe they have a dedicated
block on Saturday morning set aside from 9:00 to 11:00 AM. So these are our
three programs here.

And I'm going to give you a high
level overview in the next slide for these programs.

I just wanted to
show you, if you go to our website
online.stanford.edu,

this is what you'll see. You'll see the Leading People
Culture and Innovation Program, the Digital Transformation
Program, and then

the Engineering
Leadership Program. So let's take a
closer look here. There's lots of information
on these slides too.

I just want to let
during the recording, you can see these again. You have opportunity to
ask questions at the end.

Maybe at the end you're like,
dang it, I forgot something. Write in to our customer
service and excellence team,

they are so happy
to hear from people. So let's go to
this next one here.

I like to see things
like this in a matrix. I think it's super
helpful to understand what we're looking at here, so
we can compare and contrast.

So the professional
education programs, I showed you them on
the previous slide, and these are at a glance.

What are we looking at here? As Pax said, there's lots
of stuff we have here,

but it's about determining
what is the right fit for you and your learning needs.

You can see on the matrix
on the left-hand-side that many of the categories are
the same for each of the three

programs. For example, there's
no application on any of these programs. You can start any of these
programs at any time.

We have email support
from course facilitators. So if you're going through
the course, and you're like, I don't really understand what's
going on with this question.

You can hit it within
the learning system. And you can say, hey,
I have a question. And you'll get answered back
by a course facilitator.

And then where you want
to drill in here and look, is you want to say, all
right, the difference comes

in these programs in
the course topics. And so when choosing
a program or a course,

it's about who you are, where
you want to go in your career, and what you want to learn.

So for example, if
you're a people manager and you want to learn how to--

and we say here, a
learning objective, --how to elevate your team from
good to extraordinary, great. What does that mean?

What does that mean, Robyn? Maybe in the Leading People,
Culture and Innovation Program, there's a course about
leading innovation.

There's a whole slew of courses
that we have put together as an opportunity to take
multiple courses that

form a program, and you
can learn more about how to lead your
team more effectively

and how to level up some skills. Maybe you want to
learned something new. Maybe you want to have
a Stanford certificate

on your LinkedIn
and on your resume. So these are the kinds of
things that are in each program.

And then in the middle, we have
digital transformation program. And this is for leaders
of digital transformation

initiatives, and how to lead
and execute a technology enabled business transformation,
so our digital transformation

program. And then over on the right, we
have the Engineering Leadership Program. These are for current and
aspiring tech managers.

How to better communicate,
how to be a persuasive negotiator, how to be an
influential decision maker.

So it's all about exploring
on the page at Stanford about

how to, where am I at,
where do I want to go, and what skills do
I want to take in.

OK. Next slide here,
I want to show you there's a couple of ways to
engage with these programs.

You can purchase what we
call the All-Access plan. The Ali-Access Plan
is a one-time payment.

And you have the
content, all the courses within the program for a year.

A lot of people
like this option, because you can take your
time, you can go through it.

Some people will finish
a course and then maybe within their professional
role six months later,

they have a project that
lands on their desk. And they're like, oh,
I remember learning from Bob Sutton about this.

I'm going to go back
and revisit that content and pull some of
those learnings out. I personally, like to do that.

So I like the All
Access plan, because you get access for the entire year.

Or you don't have to
purchase a whole program. Maybe you look over the
programs and you're like,

I really want to level up this
skill set about negotiation. I really want this
negotiation course

within the engineering
leadership program. Great. You can buy that
course, a la carte. You can get access
to it for 60 days.

And then you'll get a digital
record of completion for that. And then if you
finish a program, you get a digital
program certificate.

So for whatever you
complete, you're going to get some sort
of digital certificate

at the end, record of
completion or certificate. But it's about what
you want to learn. It's about how much time
you have, as Pax said,

which I think,
that's a real thing. How much time do I have
to learn this new skill?

So a couple of ways
to engage there. And now what I'd
like to do is I'd

like to use the
Engineering Leadership Program as an example, so we
can look a little bit closer at

what it comprises
a program, what exactly are we talking about. So you can see here,
if you go to the page

and it's linked in your
dashboard, the Engineering Leadership Program. You can get a certificate
of completion,

if you finish four courses
within the certificate. Again, it's online.

It's self-paced. You can do the All-Access Plan. You can get one course, if you
really want to learn something.

And everything is on this page. So let's look a
little bit closer. Something I really wanted to
touch on here is specifically,

these are the instructors within
the engineering leadership program. And this is the same for all
professional education programs

that we offer in this
space and across the board. Some professional education
at other universities

will have maybe non-faculty,
non-institution people.

All the courses
within the programs are faculty who are
teaching in the courses. Sometimes they'll
invite their colleagues

and maybe from industry
to have an interview, or to provide some
teachings within the module,

or if they're masters
of that subject matter. But what brings
richness to the courses

overall is that these
are Stanford people. They're Stanford lecturers. They're Stanford faculty. So I offer this to you as a
differentiator from sometimes

what you'll see from other
higher Ed institutions. So I just wanted to
use this as an example.

Again, this is just for
the Engineering Leadership as an example.

So on the course page on the
Engineering Leadership Program, these are the courses
currently in the program.

Again, you can see
they're all self-paced. And then you can see an
estimate of how long it takes to complete each course.

So Becoming a Good
Leader is going to be coming out next month. We're very excited about that.

And if you look at, for example,
Communicating with Confidence-- and we're going to take
a deeper look at that-- you can see here it's
eight hours to take this.

It's online. It's self-paced. So as I say, we
have a lot of people that like to do a module
on their lunch hour,

maybe some sustained
working on the weekend. And so you can do that
really easily with these.

And then overall, for the course
structure for these programs, there's no prerequisites.

There's nothing to take that
you have to do beforehand. You can just enroll in these. For the engineering
leadership program,

it's geared towards current
and aspiring tech managers. Not inspiring, but maybe, too.

And then we have
recorded lecture with Stanford instructors and
faculty within the courses.

And we have written
exercises and multiple choice final assessment.

You can also, as I
talked about earlier, get support from course
facilitators via email, if you get stuck on
something, or maybe

you have an additional question. And I wanted to show you,
we talk about things,

but what does it actually look
like in the learning system? So this is a snapshot taken
from the Communicating

with Confidence course. This is Matt Vassar. And you could see, he's
talking about how are you

going to get very specific
strategies for communication. Over on the right-hand-side,
you can see the slide deck,

which is downloadable. And then if you toggle--
there's a switch-- you can also get a transcript
of what's being said to you,

and you can follow
along that way. So the lectures are divided
up into small video chunks,

so that you're not
sitting in front of something for 45 minutes. Generally, our video clips
for faculty lecturing

are under 10 minutes each. There's a lot of three
minutes or maybe five minutes. It depends on what makes
most sense for the content

that you're learning.  As I mentioned earlier, we have
exercises within our courses.

These are all self-paced. There's open response
and reflective questions.

So Matt Vassar is
asking you, hey, as you think about
your elevator pitch, ask yourself, what's
my 10% message?

What's part of my
elevator pitch? So these are prompting you
to work on something maybe

you've had for a while
that you're like, I really need to get better at crafting
the response when somebody says, what do you do?

Or what's your message
about this topic? And so these are
the kinds of things that are within the
courses within the business

and leadership programs. And I've reached the
end here of my portion,

and Pax is going to take it
away for credit-bearing courses. But don't forget, at
the end we have-- that

was a lot of information, 100%. It's like drinking
from the fire hose. But we have a Q&A
session at the end.

Please feel free to
put any questions in. And if I don't have
the answer, then I will go away, find the
answer, and email it to you.

But I will do my best
to answer questions. Thanks, everybody. Pax, take it away. PAX HEHMEYER: Thanks, Robyn.

So I'm going to talk
about the opportunity to take credit-bearing
courses online through the Center for
Global and Online Education.

So as Robyn said, in terms
of the professional offerings in the business and
leadership space,

they tend to be self-paced
and fully online. So one big
differentiator is these

are not self-paced classes. This is your chance to
take an actual class that's

happening at Stanford, to join
that class while on campus students are also taking it. You will join as
an online student.

There's a small caveat
there, which I'll get to. But you are in the same class. You're going to follow along
with all the assignments

in the quarter. So that's a 10 week quarter
with usually one week for exams, for final exams.

So you're following along. You're doing all
the same assignments as on campus students. You're taking the same exams.

You're following
the same deadlines. It's intensive. What we like to say, is
it's both an opportunity

and a challenge. It's an opportunity because
this isn't an extension program. You're just taking the same
course that on campus students

are taking, and you're
joining as an online student. On the other hand, it's a
challenge because of course,

you're probably not
a full time student. You're balancing work and life. And maybe you're
taking one course.

And you're going to
need to follow along like all the full-time students
with a quarter long course

that's very intensive. And a lot of these courses-- most of the courses are
graduate level courses in the School of Engineering.

And I'll get into what
kind of business content we have in the School
of Engineering. But they're going
to be, most of them,

probably between 15 to 20 hours
a week of work across 10 weeks. So they're very
intensive courses.

They're going to go in depth. So as Robyn was saying, as
you're thinking about where you

are and what you're
trying to achieve, these are the kinds of
courses that are going to go in much greater depth.

There are a lot of them
are very quantitative, even on the business side of things. And they're going to
be very structured.

They're going to allow you
to really learn and master that material. But they are a tremendous
time commitment.

And also, the other thing, it's
not just how much time you have. It's that kind of cadence,
when you can commit that time.

So if you're just able to
do one lunch break a week, maybe a professional
course is right for you.

But if you can commit
significant time each week over a 10-week period, then maybe a
credit-bearing course is right

for you. So what are these
credit-bearing courses? Well, so every year
the Stanford Online,

the Center for Global and Online
Education, we extend about 200 of the engineering classes
that are happening on campus.

We open them up to individuals
like yourself to apply and enroll in those classes.

And you apply and enroll in
a course-by-course basis. As I said, if you're
accepted in the course,

and you take the course,
you're doing all the same work as on campus students,
you're following along,

you're maybe joining
office hours over Zoom, you're joining the chats,
you're watching recordings

of the lectures that
are happening on campus, so you're engaging
in the same way that most of on campus
students are engaging,

and you're just a student in
that class, and at the end of it you're going to earn
a Stanford transcript,

just like on campus students,
and you will earn a grade. Now, what makes it a
little bit more flexible

than if you're a
matriculated student is that you don't need to
take a course every quarter.

You can apply any
quarter that there's a course that interests you. And so maybe you see something
I talk about today that you're

interested in this
spring, and you apply to enroll in that
course this spring. You look at the summer
offerings and say, yeah, there's

nothing there for me. There's nothing there
for you in the fall. But in the winter you
see another course that interests you. Great.

Well, then you apply to
enroll in that course. And every time you apply, you
submit an application once.

We keep it on file. And every time you're interested
in enrolling in a course, we submit that application to
the relevant department who

will review your application. They'll also review
your Stanford transcript as you begin to take courses.

And they're going to take
a look at those things, make sure you meet the
prerequisites for the course, the Department
level prerequisites,

review how you're
doing at Stanford. And then they will
make a decision about whether you
can take that course. And as you continue
to do well, you

can continue to take courses. So there is some
flexibility within there. And a lot of our
learners are people

who maybe aren't interested. They may already have
advanced degrees. They might already
have a master's degree. Maybe you already have a
PhD, and you're really not

interested in going back
and getting another degree. What you are
interested in, is maybe you got that master's
degree 10 years ago,

and there have been some
advances in x or y field, and you want to fill in
that gap in your knowledge,

because it's been 10 years. Great. You can come back and
take that single course. Or maybe you
already have an MBA.

But what you're
interested in now is getting some more technical
or quantitative decision analysis skills.

But you need some great depth. So you're coming back to
take some of those courses. So we have a lot of those
students who already

have advanced degrees, aren't
interested in a degree, are just interested in one
or two in-depth courses.

Maybe you're thinking
about graduate school. You're not quite sure
if it's right for you. Maybe you're thinking
about Stanford.

Well, this is your
chance to also take a graduate course at Stanford
and see what it's like.

Now, if you were admitted into
a master's degree in the School of Engineering at Stanford,
you can apply up to 18 units

that you earn as what we
call a non-degree student towards that degree, again, as
long as they're relevant units, and you're admitted into
that degree program.

Now in addition to degrees,
if you are-- as I said, this is a course-by-course. You're applying on a
course-by-course basis.

We do offer about
30 certificates. These are accredited
certificates. They're usually collections
of three to five classes.

And if you complete those three
to five classes in three years, then you will also
earn a certificate. Now, you don't need to
pursue a certificate.

You can just do
individual courses, but that's also an option. If you want to get more out
of that learning experience

than just the course
experience and the transcript, you can work towards
a certificate.

Now, I've already said
some of these things, but to talk about
the business content

particularly that's within
the credit-bearing portfolio. As I said, we are within
the School of Engineering.

And these are for the most
part, graduate level courses within the School
of Engineering. So they do tend to be geared
towards either leaders who

are managing
engineering teams or who are using technical skills
to make decisions, so

quantitative decision analysis. Stanford is well known for a
lot of courses around intra-

and entrepreneurship,
especially for technology based courses or companies.

So we have a lot of
those kinds of programs. And I'll go into a little bit of
detail about what's available.

These of course, are being
taught by Stanford faculty. Sometimes they do bring
in industry professionals, either is the same with
our professional programs

to provide that
valuable context. And by the way, I
should pause here. This is one reason
why faculty like

to have people like
you in these classrooms as well, because
many of you might be working in a technology firm
or at another kind of firm.

And you're going to be
coming into the classroom as a more experienced
leader who's bringing that
practical experience,

and may be applying what
you're learning about right now in your work. And that's why
faculty do love having

this opportunity to bring
professionals like yourself into the classroom.

As I said, usually, you're going
to be engaging with the teaching team in just the same way an
on campus student would be.

Again, you may not be able to
come in person for the office hours, but they should have some
online office hours usually held

over a program like Zoom. A lot of them will have
some discussion forum where most of the
students are posting,

and that's where you could
also answer or ask questions and engage with the material.

These classes are,
for the most part, happening and scheduled
in Stanford classrooms.

We're recording them. We're broadcasting them. There may not be an opportunity
to ask questions live. These are often large
lecture classes,

but you'll be able to watch the
recordings at your convenience. Again, it's not the same
as a self-paced course.

These are over 10 week periods. So you're probably
going to need to watch those lectures within a
day of them occurring,

so that you can begin working
on whatever the next assignment or problem set is that
you need to submit.

And again, as I said,
you are responsible for the same assignments and exams. And I said at the
beginning, there

wasn't one caveat about
these being fully online. If there are in-person
exams for that course, you will need to
make arrangements

wherever you are to take
that exam in person. And that usually
involves working with someone at your job,
maybe your supervisor or an HR

representative to work with us
to deliver that exam in person, or going to a testing center
or a library that's nearby

and making arrangements to
take those exams in person. So I did want to
put that one caveat.

So let me talk a little
bit about what kinds of-- and we have a lot. Again, there are over
200 engineering courses

that are available each
year for you to explore. But in terms of the business
transformation and leadership

side, I think of it as
three broad categories. So we have what I would
call technical management. These tend to be, as I said,
around quantitative decision

making. So these are three examples. These are core courses
within the Management Science and Engineering Department.

These are core courses
in their master's degree. So these are things like
Probabilistic Analysis, Stochastic Modeling,
Introduction to Optimization.

If that's exciting
to you, then these might be the right kinds
of courses for you. They will require a strong
quantitative background already,

in order to be able
to engage in these. So these will tend to require
that you already have maybe even

multivariable calculus, but at
least single variable calculus, probably some linear
algebra under your belt, some probability of statistics.

So these are pretty advanced
quantitative classes. And what they will
teach you to do is to harness
those tools to make

better decisions as a leader. Now, in addition to
those, we do have what I would call or think of
as more traditional management

courses. Some of these also will
require a technical background. But for instance, this spring
we have organizational behavior.

This is taking a look at
how organizations behave. How do you structure an
organization effectively? This is co-taught by a longtime
industry leader and one

of our faculty-- in fact, the chair of the MS&E
Department-- this quarter. Then we have the
ethical analyst.

This is exactly what it says,
is how do you analyze and think about the decisions
you make ethically?

How do you build your own
personal ethical framework for making decisions? And by the way, if I
remember correctly,

is the big final project,
is putting together your own ethical framework
that you can then carry forward into your decisions as a leader.

And then finally,
traditional courses like Accounting for
Managers and Entrepreneurs. And finally, as I said, we do
have a ton of entrepreneurship

and Intrapreneurship classes. So these are courses like
Global Entrepreneurship Without

Borders, which
looks at how do you build a global
entrepreneurial organizations. The entrepreneurial management
and finance course--

we just had an informational
session on that. That's going to walk you through
a simulation of the first-- the way the instructor
said, is it's

the first 10 years of a startup. So you walk through everything
from the first funding

rounds, all the way to an exit. And it simulates
that, and lets you get a sense of what that's like. And then finally,
there are courses

like this Career
Building course, which is in the chemical
engineering department. And it's led by a faculty member
who is a chemical engineer,

but is also found
in many companies. And it's an opportunity for-- it's directed towards a lot
of matriculated students

who are thinking
about their careers and how you translate research
into commercial ventures.

So these are the kinds
of courses that we have at the credit-bearing level. Again, they're not self-paced.

You're going to be following
along in the 10 week quarter. You're going to be doing
all the same assignments.

What the experience
is like is going to vary a lot between
the different courses, depending on how the faculty
set it up, just like they

would at any other University. But it's a very
exciting opportunity

for people who are
interested in maybe, again, filling that one gap they
have or interested in trying out

a graduate program. In terms of how you
can take these courses,

you do need to apply
for these courses. As I said, you are approved
on a course-by-course basis.

So you're not admitted
into any program. Your application
is kept on file. And every time you want
to enroll in a course,

your application
will be resubmitted. And as you begin
to take courses, it will be resubmitted with
your Stanford transcript.

And they will be reviewed
by the relevant department. And each department has
different department level standards.

And then there are, of
course, the prerequisites for the course. That said, the application
is fairly simple. It's not like applying
to grad school.

We do need a
statement of purpose. We ask for some
personal information, your professional background.

And we do need also, your
educational background. You do need a conferred
undergraduate degree in order

to take these courses, because
they are graduate level courses. And so you would upload your
educational transcripts.

And that's the application
we'd keep on file, and we would be sharing
with the departments. We do not review
your application

until you enroll in a course. And we don't review
it, the departments do. So once you enroll
in a course, we

would forward that to
the relevant department. They would review it, and
they would make a decision

about whether or not to approve
you for that particular course. And every time you enroll
in a course, again, we would be resubmitting
that application

to the relevant department. Now, if you're interested,
spring enrollments or enrollment for spring quarter, which begins
on March 31, is open right now.

It closes this Sunday, March
16th, at 11:59 PM, Pacific time.

So if you're interested in any
of those courses or programs that I mentioned earlier, again,
go to online.stanford.edu,

take a look at what's
available, and you can submit an application. As Robyn said, that was very
much drinking from a fire hose.

So we wanted to give this chance
to come back and just give you an overview. We'll keep this up
for a little bit

so you can look at the
full range of offerings. Again, the first three columns
are the specific programs

within the professional program. And that fourth column
covers a wide variety of courses and content within
the Stanford Online portfolio.

One thing I didn't mention
is that very bottom row, is the pricing. Again, for the
credit-bearing courses,

you're essentially paying
tuition for a single course, and that's calculated
on a per unit basis.

I've put the tuition
for this academic year down there at the bottom.

At that, let's leave this
up for a little while.

And I see we have a
couple of questions. ROBYN WOODMAN: Yeah, I think
that's a great idea, Pax. Let's leave this up.

And maybe we can start
answering questions. I can start here on some
of the earlier questions

that came in about the
engineering leadership program.
